channel.title: Comments on: Hershey Residence/Castle Towers – 350 South Grand/750 West Fourth

item.title: By: karwelis
item.dc:creator: karwelis
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://www.onbunkerhill.org/hershey_castletowers/#comment-33">Decoy</a>.
the unfortunate truth of the mater is, a short while after they were moved a transiant started a fire in the fire place of one of the homes burning both to the ground. <a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/31599573@N03/2958273313/" title="00059373 by karwelis, on Flickr"><img src="https://farm4.static.flickr.com/3291/2958273313_c6a6a26ed2_o.jpg" alt="00059373" height="574" width="720" /></a> bunker hill is worth the effort
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Decoy.

the unfortunate truth of the mater is, a short while after they were moved a transiant started a fire in the fire place of one of the homes burning both to the ground.

bunker hill is worth the effort

item.title: By: inLAonLA

item.description:

https://inlaonla.blogspot.com/

item.title: By: Victorian Gentleman 1867
item.dc:creator: Victorian Gentleman 1867
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://www.onbunkerhill.org/hershey_castletowers/#comment-33">Decoy</a>.
Hello Decoy, I am a volunteer and researcher for Heritage Square Musuem. I am also the Executive Curator of an upcoming exhibit entitled, "The Long Road Home: History of Heritage Square". This exhibit will focus primarily on the buildings we currently have but will also contain information about the museum's beginnings with the Castle and Salt Box. The exhibit opens December 1st and will run through March, 2009. 2009 will also mark our 40th Anniversary and will host a large variety of events and exhibits about Los Angeles and also a 'walk' to commemorate the move of the Castle and Salt Box from Bunker Hill to the Heritage Square. Victorian Gentleman 1867 Los Angeles, CA
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Decoy.

Hello Decoy,
I am a volunteer and researcher for Heritage Square Musuem. I am also the Executive Curator of an upcoming exhibit entitled, "The Long Road Home: History of Heritage Square". This exhibit will focus primarily on the buildings we currently have but will also contain information about the museum’s beginnings with the Castle and Salt Box. The exhibit opens December 1st and will run through March, 2009. 2009 will also mark our 40th Anniversary and will host a large variety of events and exhibits about Los Angeles and also a ‘walk’ to commemorate the move of the Castle and Salt Box from Bunker Hill to the Heritage Square.
Victorian Gentleman 1867
Los Angeles, CA

item.title: By: Decoy
item.dc:creator: Decoy
item.description: After reading <a href="https://www.onbunkerhill.org/salt_box">another article</a>, I learned that the house was set fire by vandals along with <a href="https://www.onbunkerhill.org/salt_box">The Salt Box</a> before the move was completed.
item.content:encoded: After reading another article, I learned that the house was set fire by vandals along with The Salt Box before the move was completed.

item.title: By: Decoy
item.dc:creator: Decoy
item.content:encoded:
Good blog post but I am a bit confused about this structure’s current whereabouts. I’m not sure if I missed something but What actually happened to this structure? Was it eventually demolished?

The opening paragraph states: “When the Castle and Salt Box were physically moved from Bunker Hill to Heritage Square in Highland Park, it was probably a sight most residents had never seen.”

I looked up Heritage Square in Highland Park but did not see this structure listed there on their website.

The closing statement reads: “As for the former residence-turned-apartment building, the Castle Towers and its residents lived a peaceful existence and until the mid-1950s when the Community Redevelopment Agency came a callin’.”

It’s not really clear to me what “when the Community Redevelopment Agency came a callin'” means exactly.

Thanks
